basics.name: Joshua Kosakowsky
basics.label: Business Analyst
basics.summary: Business Analyst with a track record of driving growth and innovation through strategic analysis, leadership, and a deep understanding of both business and technology landscapes.

work.name: United States Air Force Reserves
work.summary: Leveraging innovation and leadership, I've enhanced team training efficiency and global mission performance by creating a pivotal technical resource platform. My expertise in managing complex maintenance tasks and nurturing collaboration among diverse teams underscores my commitment to operational excellence.

volunteer.summary: Enhancing efficiency and user experience through advanced Salesforce automation and bespoke configurations, while ensuring platform security and optimal performance with tailored application development to meet specific organizational needs.
highlights: Created a Salesforce platform from the ground up for HOA use.
Improved residents accessibility to Forms, Maintenance Requests, and Housing Notifications.

awards.title: The Air Force Achievement Medal
awards.summary: Awarded for initiating process improvements and leadership in operations, directly enhancing operational efficiency and mission capability, and contributing significantly to team achievements and military excellence.

publications.name: Zur Elektrody/namik bewegter Körper
publications.summary: It concerned an interpretation of the Michelson–Morley experiment and the properties of light and time. Special relativity incorporates the principle that the speed of light is the same for all inertial observers regardless of the state of motion of the source.

publications.name: Über einen die Erzeugung und Verwandlung des Lichtes betreffenden heuristischen Gesichtspunkt
publications.summary: In the second paper, he applied the quantum theory to light to explain the photoelectric effect. In particular, he used the idea of light quanta (photons) to explain experimental results, but stressed the importance of the experimental results. The importance of his work on the photoelectric effect earned him the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1921.

publications.name: Die Grundlage der allgemeinen Relativitätstheorie
publications.summary: The publication of the theory of general relativity made him internationally famous. He was professor of physics at the universities of Zurich (1909–1911) and Prague (1911–1912), before he returned to ETH Zurich (1912–1914).
